journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Adaptive fuzzy H∞ control strategy for a micro-electromechanical system gyroscope based on the linear matrix inequality approach

contrib-group.aff: Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Power Transmission and Distribution Equipment Technology, Hohai University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Juntao Fei, Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Power Transmission and Distribution Equipment Technology, College of Computer and Information, Hohai University, Changzhou, 213022, People’s Republic of China. Email: jtfei@yahoo.com

abstract.p: In this paper, an adaptive fuzzy logic controller is proposed to create a H∞ tracking performance for a micro-electro-mechanical system gyroscope with system non-linearity consisting of parameter uncertainties and external disturbances. An adaptive fuzzy logic system is used to approximate the non-linear function to compensate the system’s non-linear behavior. Riccati-type equations and the linear matrix inequality technique are incorporated into the direct adaptive fuzzy H∞ control. The influence of both fuzzy logic approximation error and external disturbances on the tracking error is attenuated to a prescribed level. Simulation results confirm that the effect of both the fuzzy approximation error and external disturbance on the tracking error can be attenuated efficiently by the proposed methods. Compared with the Riccati-type equation-based approach, the linear matrix inequality-based approach creates a better tracking performance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Micro-electromechanical system (MEMS) gyroscopes are finding extensive use as micro sensors for measuring angular velocity due to their compact size, low cost and high sensitivity. Most MEMS gyroscopes are based on the Coriolis force and are driven by an electrostatic force and use capacitive detection. Fabrication imperfections result in cross-stiffness and damping effects and the performance of the MEMS gyroscope deterioriates due to the time-varying effects of quadrature errors and external disturbances. Therefore, it is necessary to utilize advanced control methods, such as sliding mode control and intelligent control, to measure the angular velocity and minimize the cross-coupling terms.

Leland1 proposed the adaptive control of a MEMS gyroscope using Lyapunov methods in which controllers tune the natural frequency of the drive axis to a preselected frequency and drive the vibration of the sensing axis to zero for force-to-rebalance operation. Batur and Sreeramreddy2 developed sliding mode control for a MEMS gyroscope system. Sung and Lee3 derived a phase-domain design approach to study the mode-matched control of a gyroscope. Park et al.4 presented an adaptive controller for a MEMS gyroscope which was used to drive both the axes of vibration and control the entire operation of the gyroscope. Zheng et al.5 developed an active disturbance rejection control for a MEMS gyroscope. Antonello et al.6 presented an extremum-seeking control method for automatic mode matching in MEMS vibrating gyroscopes. Ma et al.7 proposed a compact H∞ robust rebalance loop control for MEMS gyroscopes. Dong and Avanesian8 derived a design methodology and hardware implementation for the drive-mode control of vibrational MEMS gyroscopes. Dong et al.9 presented a control circuitry design for both vibrating axes of gyroscopes, and a novel sensing method for time-varying rotation rates. Trusov et al.10 proposed low-dissipation silicon-based tuning fork gyroscopes for rate and whole angle measurements. Adaptive sliding mode control approaches for a MEMS gyroscope have been proposed in Fei and Chowdhury11 and Fei and Batur.12 Recently, extensive research has been performed on the application of intelligent control approaches to approximate non-linear systems. Intelligent control approaches have been applied to represent complex plants and construct advanced controllers. In the last few years, fuzzy control has been extensively applied in a wide variety of industrial systems and consumer products due to its model-free approach. However, the proposed fuzzy control algorithms depend on expert information and do not possess analytical tools that guarantee basic performance criteria. An adaptive fuzzy logic system is a system whose parameters can be adjusted according to numerical input/output data. Wang13 proposed the universal approximation theorem and demonstrated that an arbitrary function of a given set of functions can be approximated with an arbitrary accuracy using a fuzzy system on a compact domain. Therefore, the ability of a fuzzy logic system to approximate arbitrary non-linear functions makes it a useful tool for adaptive applications. There are many applications of other control methods combined with adaptive fuzzy control systems. Guo and Woo14 proposed an adaptive fuzzy sliding mode controller for a robotic manipulator. Tong and Zhou15 designed fuzzy indirect and direct adaptive controls for non-linear systems. Yoo and Ham16 developed an adaptive controller for a robotic manipulator using a fuzzy compensator.

In the last decade, H∞ control theory has been developed and extensively applied to efficiently treat robust stabilization and disturbance rejection problems. There is the opportunity to combine conventional H∞ optimal control with adaptive fuzzy control. Chen et al.17 proposed a method of using both direct and indirect adaptive fuzzy controls combined with H∞ optimal control to achieve a desired attenuation of disturbances created by the approximation error and external noise. Tong and Chai18 presented an adaptive fuzzy control method for a class of continuous uncertainty system. Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy logic systems were used to approximate unknown functions and H∞ control was used to attenuate the effect on the tracking error caused by fuzzy logic approximation errors and external disturbance.

Riccati-type equation approaches and linear matrix inequality (LMI)-based approaches have been applied to the standard H∞ control problem to design robust state feedback controllers. Deng19 developed a LMI method for adaptive H∞ control that was based on fuzzy basis functions and presented an algorithm for online self-adjustment by means of altering the fuzzy rules basis that made the control system globally stable. Choi20 proposed a LMI-based sliding surface design method for integral sliding mode control of mismatched uncertain systems.

This paper is focused on the design of an adaptive fuzzy H∞ robust control strategy for the vibration of a MEMS gyroscope using the LMI approach. The adaptive fuzzy control is combined with H∞ control based on LMI and Riccati-type equations. Lyapunov stability analysis and robust tracking simulations are performed using Riccati-type equations and LMI, respectively. The contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows.

list-item.p: The novelty in the controller design lies in that an adaptive fuzzy controller is used to approximate an ideal control law and a robust compensator is designed to attenuate the effect of the approximation error to a prescribed level so as to achieve the H∞ tracking performance. For the adaptive intelligent controller the adaptive fuzzy control methodology is integrated with the H∞ control technique by solving LMIs to achieve intelligent robust control

Adaptive fuzzy control and H∞ control are proposed to adjust the system parameters to attenuate the tracking error to a prescribed level and then achieve the H∞ tracking control performance. The H∞ control technique based on LMIs is combined with an adaptive control algorithm and fuzzy approximation method to achieve the desired attenuation of the disturbance due to the approximation error and external noise in MEMS gyroscopes created by a large uncertainty or unknown variation in plant parameters and structure. Using the LMI-based approach, the system has a more accurate tracking property and stronger robustness in the presence of model uncertainties and external disturbances in the MEMS gyroscope model. It can better accommodate the gyroscope system in the following steps. The proposed controller is divided into two parts, one is an adaptive fuzzy controller that is used to approximate an ideal control law and the other is a robust compensator that is designed to attenuate the effect of the approximation error to a prescribed level so as to achieve the H∞ tracking performance.

A fuzzy H∞ control based on LMI is used to adaptively approximate and compensate the unknown model uncertainties and external disturbances. Riccati-type equations and LMIs are incorporated with direct adaptive fuzzy H∞ control to approximate the non-linear function to compensate the system’s non-linear behavior. The proposed adaptive fuzzy controller guarantees the stability of the closed-loop system and improves the robustness to external disturbances and model uncertainties.

sec.title: Dynamics of a MEMS tri-axial gyroscope
sec.p: The dynamics of a MEMS gyroscope are described in this section. A typical MEMS vibratory gyroscope configuration includes: (i) a proof mass suspended by spring beams; (ii) electrostatic actuation and sensing mechanisms for forcing an oscillatory motion and sensing the position and velocity of the proof mass, respectively; and (iii) a rigid frame which is rotated along the rotation axis. The dynamics of a MEMS gyroscope are derived from Newton’s law in the rotating frame.

In a z-axis gyroscope, by assuming that the stiffness of the spring in the z-direction is much larger than that in x and y directions, the motion of the proof mass is constrained to be only along the x–y plane as shown in Figure 1. Assuming that the angular velocity
Ω
z
is time-varying and taking fabrication imperfections into account, which cause extra coupling between the x and y axes, the governing equations for a z-axis MEMS gyroscope can be derived as

are the Coriolis forces. When the gyroscope experiences an external angular velocity, the Coriolis forces cause the mode to vibrate at the driven frequency whose amplitude is proportional to the angular rate. By demodulating the output signal at the driven frequency, the value of the angular rate can be obtained. The coupled spring and damping terms are unknown, but can be assumed to be small. The nominal values of the spring and damping terms along the x and y axes are known, but there are small unknown variations. The proof mass can be determined accurately.

sec.title: Adaptive fuzzy H∞ control
sec.p: Fuzzy logic systems are universal approximations from the viewpoint of human experts and can uniformly approximate non-linear continuous functions to an arbitrary accuracy. In the direct adaptive fuzzy control case, in order to achieve a H∞ control design, the adaptive control algorithm is approximated by adjusting the parameters of an appropriate fuzzy logic system.

The fuzzy logic systems are constructed from fuzzy If–Then rules using specific inference, fuzzification, and defuzzification strategies. The fuzzy inference engine uses the fuzzy If–Then rules to perform a mapping from an input linguistic vector

sec.title: Adaptive fuzzy H∞ control based on LMIs
sec.p: The advantages of the LMI approach compared with the Riccati-type equation approach can be summarized as follows. First, the former obtains the H∞ controller by solving a LMI whereas the latter does it through solving a Riccati-type equation. Therefore, the LMI approach can solve the problems which exist in traditional control approaches, such as the Hamiltonian matrix having singular eigenvalue problems on the imaginary axis and so on. Second, solving Riccati-type equations can only result in one aspect of the performance required to meet the optimal solution whereas the LMI method can be a solution set that can meet all the various aspects of the performance. Third, Riccati-type equations often rely on the adjustment of parameters, and thus cannot be optimized for certain performances, whereas the LMI avoids this problem. Therefore, a control method based on the LMI approach will now be presented.
A block diagram of adaptive fuzzy H∞ control based on LMIs is shown in Figure 2. The adaptive fuzzy logic system can be written as

sec.p: Figures 4–11 compare the tracking error between the system based on the Riccati-type equation and that based on the LMI approach. It can be seen that the system based on LMIs has a better trajectory tracking performance than the system based on the Riccati-type equation. It can be observed that the obtained x and y positions track the position of the reference model after a short time, demonstrating that the adaptive fuzzy tracking performance is satisfactory. It can be concluded that the MEMS gyroscope is able to maintain the proof mass oscillations in the x and y direction at given frequency and amplitude using adaptive fuzzy control.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The H∞ control technique has been combined with an adaptive control algorithm and fuzzy approximation method in this paper to achieve a desired attenuation of the disturbance due to the approximation error and external noise in MEMS gyroscopes under a large uncertainty or unknown variation in plant parameter and structure. Direct adaptive fuzzy control algorithms based on a Riccati-type equation or LMIs have been used to treat the H∞ tracking design problem. The solvability conditions and the corresponding adaptive fuzzy control laws are both derived. A simulation example is given to illustrate the performance of the proposed methods. The simulation results confirmed that the H∞ tracking performance can be achieved using the proposed adaptive fuzzy control algorithms and demonstrated the superiority of the LMI-based approach. Using the LMI-based approach, the system has a more accurate tracking property and stronger robustness in the presence of model uncertainties and external disturbances.

Since a MEMS gyroscope is a rotation rate sensor, the major control task of a controller is to measure rotation rates. It should be noted that this paper only emphasizes the control design of the drive axis and it does not consider the estimation of the rotation rate which will be studied in future work.

ack.p: The authors thank to the anonymous reviewers for useful comments that improved the quality of the manuscript.
